Aaron Wong, Founder at The MilelionLevel 4. ProdigyAnswered on 09 Apr 2019Some do, but the problem is (1) loopholes get closed (2) banks clawback points. Case in point: BOC Elite Miles World Mastercard. In the early days, people were using this to top up YouTrip cards and cashing out by selling them. The bank eventually clawed back the points. Simliarly, during the Citi-Apple Pay 8 mpd promotion, people were using TransferWise to send money to themselves and paying with Apple Pay, effectively buying miles at a really cheap price. Citi started clawing back some of these points too. Melvin SohLevel 2. RookieAnswered on 22 Sep 2019I know some people who actively seek out opportunities to MS. However, I believe that the vast majority of mile chasers follow the letter (if not the spirit) of rules set by the bank. This minimises the risk of clawbacks from banks. Loopholes get closed eventually as no bank likes being cheated.To assess the first half of the question - it is, however, possible to travel in premium cabins (perhaps once a quarter), if you spend enough, intelligently, and exclusively on 4mpd cards (disregarding sign-up bonuses in the spirit of the question)! 100k miles round-trip in business (a generalisation, of course, this varies depending on where you're flying) is 25k spend on 4mpd cards, which if divided across 3 months is about 8k spend a month - you can get more than 8k worth of 4mpd through a series of cards - WWMC (2k), VS (2k), PPV (1k), TR Pink & Blue (2k), CRV (1k), CRMC (1k).
